text:
Southview Avenue, west side, just south of Eastern Boulevard, showing the E. H. Ludlow estate: The stone house is the main building on the estate which was known as "Black Rock."

View 3 shows the surrounding area being built up. When streets will be laid out the stone house will be in the very center of Ftley Avenue where it intersects with Banyer Place. The Ludlow house is seen facing west toward the Bronx River and is here seen from Metcalf Avenue. The swamp seen in view 3 may be part of Pine Rock Creek, which passed through the property.

Views 1, 2: E. P. Chrystie
Credit: Line Imperative

View 3: P. L. Sperr

Southview Avenue, west side, just south of Eastern Boulevard, showing the E. H. Ludlow estate: The stone house is the main building on the estate which was known as "Black Rock."

View 3 shows the surrounding area being built up. When streets will be laid out the stone house will be in the very center of Ftley Avenue where it intersects with Banyer Place. The Ludlow house is seen facing west toward the Bronx River and is here seen from Metcalf Avenue. The swamp seen in view 3 may be part of Pine Rock Creek, which passed through the property.

Views 1, 2: E. P. Chrystie
Credit: Line Imperative

View 3: P. L. Sperr

Metcalf Ave. (foreground, extending from left to right -- dirt road), at (left), and adjoining the S.E. corner of Eastern Boulevard. The frame triangular structure (left), at the corner, bears No. 1660 on the latter thoroughfare. The white frame house in the center bears No. 953 Ftley Ave.; and the old stone house, on its right stands in the middle of the latter street. On the extreme right are Nos. 943 to 939 Ftley Ave., at the head of Banyer Place. The view is eastward from the west side of Metcalf Ave.

July 30, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
